children.subject: @Lily Zhang  @Emerald Templeton  @Charlene Hughes
indeed, we are still working on new program plans. If you note the date on the link, that's from Jul 2016. We'll get a new one up there soon!  Sorry for the confusion!
OP here, https://eecs.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/lscs_sample_transfer_program_plans_jul_2016.pdf this website doesn't follow the new "EE16A or Math54 AND EE16" policy right?

history.content:
16A/B have problem sets every week which can take anywhere from 3-8 hours; for me figuring out how to use LaTeX to format the solutions into PDF was the hard part. There are also weekly labs that are usually 1-3 hours.

CS61B with Hug last semester was very manageable for me. There are 4 projects throughout the semester; 2 of them are kind of intensive (around 15-20 hours over a span of 2 weeks or so for me, although this is widely variable for other people). The labs and homeworks don't take too much time.

CS70 was the most challenging course I've taken thus far. Weekly problem sets took 8+ hours; I went to office hours every week, read nearly all the notes/extra material. I would consider 70 a heavy workload class, 16A/B medium heavy.

Hello, I'm a newly admitted intended-cs transfer student. 
I'm kind of having a hard time choosing my schedule for Fall 17 semester.
During this summer session, I'll be taking CS61A and an AC course.
None of the courses that I took in my community college doesn't articulate to any Berkeley courses, so I would have to take all lower division courses(61ABC CS70 EE16A/B).
Originally, I was going to take CS61B and CS70 over fall 17, then CS61C, EE16A, and a light upper div course over spring 17.
However, I just found out that upcoming freshman/transfer cs majors need to complete EE16A or Math54 AND EE16B. So, I need to
plan my schedule accordingly so that I don't overload my semesters, but still declare within the first semester and graduate within 5 semesters.
I do have light-mid knowledge in discrete math, data structure, and circuits (took all intro classes in my community college).
Because I don't know how heavy each course are, it's hard for me to plan a beautiful schedule.
So, please help me!
history.subject: Newly admitted Intended-CS Scheduling
